<div>
    <h1>Welcome to my site!</h1>
    <p>This site looks like this:</p>
    <img src="image.png">
    <p>Not kidding, this image is this site - with markup, styles, scripts AND IMAGES!</p>
    <p>I dare you to <b><a href="view-source:http://eirikb.github.com/pictureit/" target="_blank">look at the page source</a></b></p>
    <h2>How it works</h2>
    <p>You might wonder how I'm able to accomplish this, but in reality it's quite simple.</p>
    <p>I use RGB values to store <a href="http://www.asciitable.com/">ASCII</a> characters.<br/>
        So in RGB (Reed, Green, Blue) you have three bytes to store information (256, 256, 256).<br />
        All I have done is to generate an image based on a text file, and for each value in each pixel I fill in the ASCII value.<br />
        I do not use Alpha channel as I had problems serializing it.
    </p>
    <h3>Theory</h3>
    <p>Consider the text 'Hello world', it looks something like this in <a href="http://www.asciitable.com/">ASCII</a>: [72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 32, 119, 111, 114, 108, 100].<br />
        So I have 11 bytes I want to store in some pixels, and one pixel can hold 3 bytes, which means I need 11 chars / 3 bytes = 3.666 Ìƒ~ 4 pixels.<br />
        In the first pixel I store 'Hel' like this: <br />
        <i>getRaster().setPixel(0, 0, { 72, 101, 108 }); </i><br/>
        and for the next (' lo'): <br/> 
        <i>getRaster().setPixel(1, 0, {108, 111, 32 });</i><br/>
        And continue until all bytes are stored in the image. Note that I need to fill up the rest of the pixels with spaces.<br />
        I have made a simple java-program that can do this, and the source for this is on <a href="https://github.com/eirikb/pictureit/blob/master/java/src/no/eirikb/pictureit/PictureIt.java">github</a>.
    </p>    
    <h3>Images</h3>
    <p>
        For inline images I can either use css sprites or something much funnier: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_URI_scheme">Data URI!</a><br />
        They will basically let me print images as Base64. So all images you see on this page (including background) are Base64 encoded as text into the orignal image!
    </p>
    <h3>Illustration</h3>
    <p>This illustration might give an idea:</p>
    <img class='image' src='data:image/jpeg;base64,'/>
    <h3>Reading pixel data</h3>
    <p>To read the chars from pixels in the image I use JavaScript and HTML5 Canvas element.<br />
        The script can be viewed on <a href="https://github.com/eirikb/pictureit/blob/master/pictureit.js">github</a>.
    </p>
    <h3>Smaller image</h3>
    <p>Its possible to make the image even smaller than it is now</p>
    <ul>
        <li>I'm not using the Alpha value (RGBA). This could make the image 1 / 4 smaller in scale</li>
        <li>I could use some type of <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/294297/javascript-implementation-of-gzip">compression</a> to compress bytes into the RGB values</li>
    </ul>
    <p>
        Remember even though I only have 3 (or 4) bytes in each pixel I only need 94 different characters (7 bits) for each value.<br />
        So in theory I could move bits and store 1 extra byte for each 7 bytes. Although this would only save 1 / 7.
    </p>
    <p>Although for this demo I have decided to <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KISS_principle">KISS</a></p>
